AEM13920 Portal
Getting Started

This page aims to assist users of the AEM13920 HAL driver. It provides guidance on everything from the initialization sequence to how to read the AEM's internal data.

This page is meant as a complement to the pages offered under the Libraries section, which detail the API in greater detail.

Prerequisites

To use this driver in a project, the HAL_AEM13920.h file shall be included into the main project file. Also, the following libraries should be available into the project environment:

  • HAL_AEM13920.c & HAL_AEM13920.h
  • AEM13920_RegisterMap.h & AEM13920_Common.h
  • AEM_I2C.h

These files are all gathered into the e-peas.AEM13920_DFP.x.x.x.pack.

As explained below, the four functions described into the AEM_I2C.h header file will also need to be implemented depending on the project's specific context/platform.

Status/Error codes

All of this driver's functions return a Status/Error code. As a consequence of that, the functions used to retrieve information from the AEM always take a pointer to a variable as an argument, which will be used to return the required information.

Initialization sequence

Reset Sequence

Warning
Before starting using this driver, one need to make sure the AEM is out of its reset sequence, and ready to communicate. To do so, the IRQ pin can be used, as explained into the datasheet, section 8.1.2. Throughout this document, this condition will be considered verified.

I2C Communication Interface

This driver relies on a set of functions that are used to read and write the AEM's I2C registers. These functions are platform-specific, meaning they will need to be implemented depending on the project's specific context. The AEM_I2C_Template.c file can be used to that intent. If the platform used comes with CMSIS drivers, the AEM_I2C_CMSIS.c file offers a ready-to-use implementation.

The interface requires a data structure to be set with information about the I2C communication configuration, which will need to be passed as an argument to every of this driver's functions.

The API's documentation, available under the I2C Communication interface section, further details these aspects.

Initialization

Once the I2C interface correctly configured, a call to the AEM13920_Initialize() function will allow to initialize the interface, and the driver will then be ready to be used.

Configuring the AEM

This driver provides two ways of configuring the AEM13920:

First alternative

The AEM needs to be completely configured. In that case a AEM13920_Config variable must be declared and set according to the desired configuration. Then, passing this variable to the function AEM13920_Configure() will update the AEM behavior accordingly.

This alternative will reduce the overhead related to the communication interface: a single transfer will set the entire configurable area of the I2C registers (bulk transfer), and trigger the synchronization of the system registers along the way.

AEM_i2c_cfg my_aem_i2c_cfg;
my_aem_i2c_cfg.usr_callback = my_callback;
my_aem_i2c_cfg.interface = 0;
my_aem_i2c_cfg.slaveAddress = AEM13920_I2CSLAVE_ADDRESS;
AEM13920_Config my_aem_cfg;
// Fill in the value in mV, so that the temperature thresholds can be computed
my_aem_cfg.Rdiv = 22000000;
// Get the current configuration (i.e. reset values)
AEM13920_GetConfiguration(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &my_aem_cfg);
// Set the data structure with the required configuration settings
my_aem_cfg.src2ReguMode = AEM13920_SRCREGU_CONST;
my_aem_cfg.src2ReguV = 1900;
my_aem_cfg.apmMode = AEM13920_APM_MODE_POWER_METER;
my_aem_cfg.apmWindow = AEM13920_APM_WINDOW_128;
my_aem_cfg.enableAPMSRC2 = true;
my_aem_cfg.enableHPBoost2 = true;
my_aem_cfg.irq.enableDischarge = true;
my_aem_cfg.irq.enableOvercharge = true;
my_aem_cfg.irq.enableAPMDone = true;
my_aem_cfg.irq.enableOutOfReset = true;
// ...
// Load the configuration into the registers, and update the AEM
AEM13920_Configure(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &my_aem_cfg);

Second alternative

Only some specific configuration elements need to be updated. In this case, the relevant SetXXX, EnableXXX or DisableXXX functions can be called. That way, only the relevant registers will be written. Then, the AEM13920_LoadConfiguration() function should be called so that the system registers are synchronized with the configuration set into the I2C registers.

AEM_i2c_cfg my_aem_i2c_cfg;
my_aem_i2c_cfg.usr_callback = my_callback;
my_aem_i2c_cfg.interface = 0;
my_aem_i2c_cfg.slaveAddress = AEM13920_I2CSLAVE_ADDRESS;
// Only set the temperature monitoring feature
AEM13920_EnableTemperatureMonitoring(&my_aem_i2c_cfg);
// Update the AEM accordingly
AEM13920_LoadConfiguration(&my_aem_i2c_cfg);
AEM13920_EnableTemperatureMonitoring
int32_t AEM13920_EnableTemperatureMonitoring(const AEM_i2c_cfg *i2cCfg)
Enable the monitoring of the ambient temperature.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:1297
AEM13920_LoadConfiguration
int32_t AEM13920_LoadConfiguration(const AEM_i2c_cfg *i2cCfg)
Update the AEM's behavior according to the configuration set into the I2C registers.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:1458

Reading the configuration of the AEM

Warning
Please note that when using this driver's functions to read the AEM's configuration, the functions actually return the configuration set into the I2C registers. If some changes have been made using the AEM13920_SetXXX, AEM13920_EnableXXX or AEM13920_DisableXXX functions without a subsequent call to AEM13920_LoadConfiguration(), the values returned by the functions AEM13920_GetXXX might not reflect the actual configuration of the AEM.

This driver provides two ways of retrieving the configuration of the AEM13920:

First alternative

A series of configuration settings need to be checked. In that case it might be more efficient to read all the configuration area in a single transaction (bulk transfer), and then to interrogate the specific settings. To do so, a call to AEM13920_GetConfiguration() will set the user's data structure, and the user will only have to read the relevant fields to retrieve the required information.

AEM13920_Config my_aem_cfg;
my_aem_cfg.Rdiv = 22000000; /* Fill in the correct value, in mOhms, so that the temperature thresholds can be computed */
AEM13920_GetConfiguration(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &my_aem_cfg);
if (my_aem_cfg.enableAPMDone) {
// ...
}
if (my_aem_cfg.irq.enableDischarge) {
// ...
}

Second alternative

Only a few number of settings need to be checked. In this case, the GetXXX functions can be called. That way, only the relevant registers will be read to retrieve the required information.

bool tempMonEn = false;
AEM13920_GetTempMonEnable(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &tempMonEn);
if (tempMonEn) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_IRQEN my_aem_irqs;
AEM13920_GetIRQConfiguration(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &my_aem_irqs);
if (my_aem_irqs.enableDischarge) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_IRQEN

Reading the AEM status and version

Retrieving the AEM's status can be done as follows:

AEM13920_Status status;
AEM13920_GetStatus(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &status);
if(status.discharge) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_Status::discharge
bool discharge
Discharge status.
Definition: AEM13920_Common.h:541
AEM13920_Status
Status.
Definition: AEM13920_Common.h:533
AEM13920_GetStatus
int32_t AEM13920_GetStatus(const AEM_i2c_cfg *i2cCfg, AEM13920_Status *status)
Get the AEM's status.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:702

One may also want to get the chip version:

uint8_t version;
AEM13920_GetChipVersion(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &version);
AEM13920_GetChipVersion
int32_t AEM13920_GetChipVersion(const AEM_i2c_cfg *i2cCfg, uint8_t *version)
Get the chip version.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:675

Reading the AEM IRQ flags

Using the AEM's IRQ pin, when entering the dedicated interrupt service routine, one will need to know which of the AEM's interrupt actually triggered:

AEM13920_IRQFLG flags;
AEM13920_GetIRQFlags(&my_aem_i2c_cfg, &flags);
if (flags.discharge) {
// ...
}
AEM13920_IRQFLG::discharge
bool discharge
Discharge flag.
Definition: AEM13920_Common.h:354

Get the AEM's interrupt flags.
Definition: HAL_AEM13920.c:733

Reading the AEM's data

Various functions can be used to retrieve the AEM's generated data:

  • AEM13920_GetAPMDataSRC(),
  • AEM13920_GetAPMDataBuck(),
  • AEM13920_GetAPMError(),
  • AEM13920_GetThermistorZ(),
  • AEM13920_GetSourceRegulationVoltage(), and
  • AEM13920_GetStorageVoltage()
  • Use pursuant NDA
